6.2.6 /r/project/execute/flush

This call flushes executions in the history on the specified project.

Flushing an execution deletes both the R console output and the generated results associated with that execution but does not remove the execution itself from the history. By omitting the execution parameter, the caller can flush every execution in the history on the specified project.

This flushing facility is provided to help users manage the levels of resource usage associated with their persistent projects.

HTTP Method

POST

Request Format

Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=utf-8

Parameters

  • format – specifies markup encoding on the call: json or xml
  • project – specifies the project identifier
  • execution - (optional) comma-separated list of execution identifiers

Examples 

format=json
project=PROJECT-e2edd15f-dd67-42f6-8d82-90a2a5a669ca
execution=EXEC-ab611f28-922f-4bdc-9659-f0b83aca032b

Response Markup (JSON)

{
    "deployr": {
        "response": {
            "call": "/r/project/execute/flush",
            "success": true,
            "project": {
                "name": "Demo Analysis",
                "project": "PROJECT-e2edd15f-dd67-42f6-8d82-90a2a5a669ca",
                "descr": "Predicting retail sales."
                "longdescr": null,
                "author": "george",
                "authors": [
                    "george"
                ],
                "shared": false,
                "lastmodified": 1378320424751,
                "live": true,
                "cookie": null,
                "origin": "Project original."
            },
            "httpcookie": "675987FAFA41B1F169CFC5AB3EC5F563"
        }
    }
}

Response Markup (XML)

<deployr>
  <response>
    <call>/r/project/execute/flush</call>
    <success>true</success>
    <project>
      <project>PROJECT-e2edd15f-dd67-42f6-8d82-90a2a5a669ca</project>
      <name>Demo Analysis</name>
      <descr>Predicting retail sales.</descr>
      <longdescr/>
      <shared/>
      <author>george</author>
      <authors>
        <author>george</author>
      </authors>
      <lastmodified>1378320371107</lastmodified>
      <live>true</live>
      <cookie><![CDATA[  ]]></cookie>
      <origin>Project original.</origin>
    </project>
    <httpcookie>675987FAFA41B1F169CFC5AB3EC5F563</httpcookie>
  </response>
</deployr>

6.2.7 /r/project/execute/result/list

This call lists the execution results for the specified project.

By specifying a value for the execution parameter the caller can limit the response to those results found on a specific execution or set of executions.

Important! The URLs returned in the response markup on this call remain valid for as long as the results remain part of the project.

HTTP Method

GET

Request Format

Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=utf-8

Parameters

  • format – specifies markup encoding on the call: json or xml
  • project – specifies the project identifier
  • execution - (optional) specifies a comma-separated list of execution identifiers

execution=EXEC-76b503a3-3c2f-4114-b4b2-e3b1b6f88657

6.2.8 /r/project/execute/result/download

This call downloads the execution results for the specified project.

By specifying a value for the execution parameter the caller can download only results on the specified executions. By specifying a value for the filename parameter the caller can download a specific result on the specified execution.

HTTP Method

GET

Request Format

Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=utf-8

Parameters

  • format – specifies markup encoding on the call: json or xml
  • project – specifies the project identifier
  • execution - (optional) specifies a comma-separated list of execution identifiers
  • filename - (optional) specifies a result file name
  • inline - (optional) if true, the Content-Disposition response header indicating attachment is omitted

Examples 

format=json
project=PROJECT-e2edd15f-dd67-42f6-8d82-90a2a5a669ca
execution=EXEC-76b503a3-3c2f-4114-b4b2-e3b1b6f88657

Response

If a value for the filename parameter is specified on the call, then:

Content-Type: result/content-type

If the filename parameter is omitted on the call, then:

Content-Type: application/zip

6.2.9 /r/project/execute/result/delete

This call deletes the execution results for the specified project.

By specifying a value for the execution parameter the caller can delete only those results on the specified executions. By specifying a value for the filename parameter the caller can delete a specific result on the specified executions.

HTTP Method

POST

Request Format

Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=utf-8

Parameters

  • format – specifies markup encoding on the call: json or xml
  • project – specifies the project identifier
  • execution - (optional) specifies a comma-separated list of execution identifiers
  • filename - (optional) specifies a result file name

Examples 

format=json
project=PROJECT-e2edd15f-dd67-42f6-8d82-90a2a5a669ca
execution=EXEC-76b503a3-3c2f-4114-b4b2-e3b1b6f88657

Response Markup (JSON)

{
    "deployr": {
        "response": {
            "call": "/r/project/execute/result/delete",
            "success": true,
            "project": {
                "project": "PROJECT-e2edd15f-dd67-42f6-8d82-90a2a5a669ca",
                "name": "Demo Analysis",
                "descr": "Predicting retail sales."
                "longdescr": null,
                "author": "george",
                "authors": [
                    "george"

6.3 Working with the Project Workspace APIs

The project workspace APIs facilitate working with objects found in the project workspace.

Workspace Object Retrieval

  1. Retrieve a summary list of objects found in the workspace using the /r/project/workspace/list call.
  2. Retrieve a DeployR-encoded representation of one or more objects found in the workspace using the /r/project/workspace/get call.

Workspace Object Creation

Typically objects are created in the workspace when commands are executed. However, there are a number of APIs that allow the direct creation of objects in the workspace:

  1. Upload an object into the workspace from a file on the users computer using the /r/project/workspace/upload call.
  2. Transfer an object into the workspace from a URL using the /r/project/workspace/transfer call.
  3. Push an object into the workspace from a DeployR-encoded object using the /r/project/workspace/push call.

Workspace Objects and the Repository

  1. Workspace objects can be stored directly to the repository using the /r/project/workspace/store call.
  2. Repository-managed files containing R binary objects can be loaded directly to the workspace using the /r/project/workspace/load call.

6.3.1 /r/project/workspace/list

This call lists the objects in the workspace for the specified project.

HTTP Method

GET

Request Format

Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=utf-8

Parameters

  • format – specifies markup encoding on the call: json or xml
  • project – specifies the project identifier
  • root - (optional) specifies the object graph root
  • clazz - (optional) specifies the R class based filter
  • filter - (optional) specifies the R object name based filter
  • restrict - (optional) if true, limits returned objects to object types with supported DeployR-encoding
  • pagesize - (optional) specifies the page size for paging results in response markup
  • pageoffset - (optional) specifies the page offset for paging results in response markup

Examples 

format=json
project=PROJECT-4f9fe8bf-9425-4f2c-aa15-5d94818988f9

Response Markup (JSON)

{
    "deployr": {
        "response": {
            "call": "/r/project/workspace/list",
            "success": true,
            "project": {
                "name": "Demo Analysis",
                "project": "PROJECT-4f9fe8bf-9425-4f2c-aa15-5d94818988f9",
                "descr": "Predicting retail sales.",
                "longdescr": null,
                "author": "george",
                "authors": [
                    "george"
                ],
                "shared": false,
                "lastmodified": 1378321615345,
                "live": true,
                "cookie": null,

                "objects": [
                    {
                        "branch": false,
                        "rclass": "character",
                        "name": "x_character",
                        "type": "primitive",
                        "xdf": null
                    },
                    {
                        "branch": true,
                        "rclass": "data.frame",
                        "name": "x_dataframe",
                        "type": "dataframe",
                        "xdf": null
                    },
                    {
                        "branch": false,

                        "name": "x_matrix",
                        "type": "matrix",
                        "xdf": null
                    }
                ]
            },
            "httpcookie": "675987FAFA41B1F169CFC5AB3EC5F563"
        }
    }
}

6.3.2 /r/project/workspace/get

This call retrieves DeployR-encoded objects from the workspace for the specified project.

HTTP Method

GET

Request Format

Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=utf-8

Parameters

  • format – specifies markup encoding on the call: json or xml
  • project – specifies the project identifier
  • name - specifies a comma-separated list of object names
  • root - (optional) specifies the object graph root
  • start - (optional) specifies the offset into object data
  • length - (optional) specifies the segment of object data to retrieve
  • infinity - (optional) specifies a custom value for Infinity appearing in R object data returned on the call, otherwise Infinity is represented by 0x7ff0000000000000L
  • nan - (optional) specifies custom value for NaN appearing in R object data returned on the call, otherwise NaN is represented by null
  • encodeDataFramePrimitiveAsVector - (optional) if true, data.frame primitives are encoded vectors in R object data returned on call

Examples 

format=json
project=PROJECT-4f9fe8bf-9425-4f2c-aa15-5d94818988f9
name=autos_data

Response Markup (JSON)

{
    "deployr": {
        "response": {
            "call": "/r/project/workspace/get",
            "success": true,
            "project": {
                "name": "Demo Analysis",
                "project": "PROJECT-4f9fe8bf-9425-4f2c-aa15-5d94818988f9",
                "descr": "Predicting retail sales."
                "longdescr": null,
                "author": "george",
                "authors": [
                    "george"
                ],
                "shared": false,
                "lastmodified": 1378321946753,
                "live": true,
                "cookie": null,
                "origin": "Project original.",
            },
            "workspace": {
                "object": {
                    "name": "x_matrix",
                    "type": "matrix",
                    "rclass": "matrix",
                    "value": [
                        [
                            1,
                            3,
                            12
                        ],
                        [
                            2,
                            11,
                            13
                        ]
                    ]
                }
            },
            "httpcookie": "675987FAFA41B1F169CFC5AB3EC5F563"
        }
    }
}

Response Markup (XML)

<deployr>
  <response>
    <call>/r/project/workspace/get</call>

      <author>george</author>

      <live>true</live>
      <cookie><![CDATA[  ]]></cookie>
      <origin>Project original.</origin>
    </project>

      <object>
        <name>x_matrix</name>

6.3.6 /r/project/workspace/save

This call saves the workspace to a file in the working directory for the specified project.

If the name parameter is specified on the call then only the named object is saved as a binary object file to the working directory. Otherwise the entire contents of the workspace are saved.

HTTP Method

POST

Request Format

Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=utf-8

Parameters

  • format – specifies markup encoding on the call: json or xml
  • project – specifies the project identifier
  • name - (optional) specifies a named object for saving
  • descr - (optional) specifies a description to accompany the saved file
  • version - (optional) if true, the new file will be renamed to avoid overwriting

Examples 

format=json
project=PROJECT-4f9fe8bf-9425-4f2c-aa15-5d94818988f9
name=x_matrix
descr=Saved from workspace.

Response Markup (JSON)

                "longdescr": null,
                "author": "george",
                "authors": [
                    "george"
                ],
                "shared": false,
                "lastmodified": 1378321946753,
                "live": true,
                "cookie": null,
                "origin": "Project original.",

                    directory/download/
                    PROJECT-4f9fe8bf-9425-4f2c-aa15-5d94818988f9/x_matrix.rData"
                }
            },
            "httpcookie": "675987FAFA41B1F169CFC5AB3EC5F563"
        }
    }

6.3.7 /r/project/workspace/store

This call stores the workspace as a binary object to the repository.

If the name parameter is specified on the call, then only the named object is stored as a binary object in the repository. Otherwise the entire contents of the workspace are stored.

HTTP Method

POST

Request Format

Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=utf-8

Parameters

  • format – specifies markup encoding on the call: json or xml
  • project – specifies the project identifier
  • name - (optional) specifies a named object for storing
  • descr - (optional) specifies a description to accompany the saved file
  • tags - (optional) specifies tag words to associate with the repository file
  • restricted - (optional) comma-separated list of role names, which makes the file visible to authenticated users with these roles
  • shared - (optional) if true, the file will be shared , which makes the file visible to authenticated users
  • published - (optional) if true, the file will be published , which makes the file visible to authenticated and anonymous users
  • newversion - (optional) if true, the new file will be renamed to avoid overwriting

Examples 

format=json
project=PROJECT-4f9fe8bf-9425-4f2c-aa15-5d94818988f9
descr=Store from workspace.

Response Markup (JSON)

{
    "deployr": {
        "response": {
            "call": "/r/project/workspace/store",
            "success": true,
            "project": {
                "name": "Demo Analysis",

                "descr": "Predicting retail sales."
                "longdescr": null,
                "author": "george",
                "authors": [
                    "george"
                ],
                "shared": false,
                "lastmodified": 1378321946753,
                "live": true,
                "cookie": null,
                "origin": "Project original.",
            },
            "repository": {
                "file": {
                    "latestby": "george",
                    "url": "http://dhost:dport/deployr/r/
                    repository/file/download/george/x_matrix.rData",
                    "filename": "x_matrix.rData",
                    "author": "george",
                    "authors": [
                        "george"
                    ],
                    "version": null,
                    "descr": "Stored matrix from workspace."
                    "tags": null,
                    "length": 101,
                    "md5": "8a42ec2b108587b526f9c69d2e183a06",
                    "category": "R",
                    "restricted": null,
                    "shared": false,
                    "published": false,
                    "access": "Private",
                    "type": "application/octet-stream",
                    "lastModified": 1378322785349
                }
            },
            "httpcookie": "675987FAFA41B1F169CFC5AB3EC5F563"
        }
    }
}

Response Markup (XML)

        <filename>x_matrix.rData</filename>

          <author>george</author>

6.4 Working with the Project Directory APIs

The project directory APIs facilitate working with files found in the project working directory.

Directory File Retrieval

  • Retrieve a summary list of files found in the working directory using the /r/project/directory/list call.
  • Retrieve individual files found in the working directory using the /r/project/directory/download call.
  • Retrieve a compressed archive containing all files found in the working directory using the /r/project/directory/download call.

Directory File Creation

Typically files are created in the working directory when commands are executed. However, there are a number of APIs that allow the direct creation of files in the working directory:

  • Upload a file into the working directory from a file on the users computer using the /r/project/directory/upload call.
  • Transfer a file into the working directory from a URL using the /r/project/directory/transfer call.
  • Write a text file into the working directory using the /r/project/directory/write call.

Directory Files and the Repository

  • Store directory files directly to the repository using the /r/project/directory/store call.
  • Load repository-managed files directly into the working directory using the /r/project/directory/load call.

6.4.1 /r/project/directory/list

This call lists working directory files for the specified project.

The filter parameter can be specified on the call to filter, the types of files returned according to their category. The following filter values are supported:

  • plot - files ending with a .png, .svg or .jpg extension
  • script - files ending with a .R or .r extension
  • R - files ending with a .rData or .rdata extension
  • data - files ending with a .csv or .xls extension
  • text - files ending with a .txt extension

HTTP Method

GET

Request Format

Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=utf-8

Parameters

  • format – specifies markup encoding on the call: json or xml
  • project – specifies the project identifier
  • filter - (optional) specifies the filter by category value

Examples 

format=json
project=PROJECT-4f9fe8bf-9425-4f2c-aa15-5d94818988f9

Response Markup (JSON)

{
    "deployr": {
        "response": {
            "call": "/r/project/directory/list",

                "name": "Demo Analysis",

                "descr": "Predicting retail sales."

                "authors": [
                    "george"

6.4.4 /r/project/directory/write

This call writes a text file into the working directory for the specified project.

HTTP Method

POST

Request Format

Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=utf-8

Parameters

  • format – specifies markup encoding on the call: json or xml
  • project – specifies the project identifier
  • filename - specifies the name of the file
  • text - specifies the text content for the file
  • delimiter - (optional) specifies a custom delimiter for text when writing multiple files, defaults to #,#
  • descr - (optional) specifies the description to be associated with the file
  • overwrite - (optional) if true, overwrites the existing file of same name

Examples 

format=json
project=PROJECT-4f9fe8bf-9425-4f2c-aa15-5d94818988f9
filename=hello.txt
text=Hello world.
descr=Sample file.

6.4.6 /r/project/directory/store

This call stores a file from the working directory to the repository.

HTTP Method

POST

Request Format

Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=utf-8

Parameters

  • format – specifies markup encoding on the call: json or xml
  • project – specifies the project identifier
  • filename - (optional) specifies the file for storing
  • descr - (optional) specifies a description to accompany the saved file
  • tags - (optional) specifies tag words to associate with repository file
  • restricted - (optional) comma-separated list of role names, which makes the file visible to authenticated users with these roles
  • shared - (optional) if true, the file will be shared , which makes the file visible to authenticated users
  • published - (optional) if true, the file will be published , which makes the file visible to authenticated and anonymous users
  • newversion - (optional) if true, the new file will be renamed to avoid overwriting

Examples 

format=json
project=PROJECT-4f9fe8bf-9425-4f2c-aa15-5d94818988f9
filename=hello.txt
descr=Sample file stored from project directory.

Response Markup (JSON) 

{
    "deployr": {
        "response": {
            "call": "/r/project/directory/store",
            "success": true,
            "project": {
                "name": "Demo Analysis",
                "authors": [
                    "testuser",
                    "sheri"
                ],
                "longdescr": null,
                "origin": "Project original.",
                "cookie": null,
                "lastmodified": 1344377536002,
                "live": true,
                "shared": false,
                "project": "PROJECT-4f9fe8bf-9425-4f2c-aa15-5d94818988f9",
                "author": "testuser",
                "descr": "Predicting retail sales, updated."
            },
           "repository": {
                "file": {
                    "filename": "hello.txt",
                    "author": "george",
                    "authors": [
                        "george"
                    ],
                    "version": null,
                    "versionmsg": null,
                    "descr": "Sample file stored from project directory."
                    "tags": null,
                    "length": 11,
                    "type": "text/plain",
                    "latestby": "george",
                    "category": "text",
                    "restricted": null,
                    "shared": false,
                    "published": false,
                    "access": "Private",
                    "md5": "5eb63bbbe01eeed093cb22bb8f5acdc3",
                    "lastModified": 1378325607408,
                    "url": "http://dhost:dport/deployr/r/repository/
                    file/download/george/hello.txt"
                }
            },
            "httpcookie": "B1B5673DC4A358407F83FD6725A8C0BF"
        }
    }

Response Markup (XML)

<deployr>
  <response>
    <call>/r/project/directory/store</call>
    <success>true</success>
    <project>
      <project>PROJECT-4f9fe8bf-9425-4f2c-aa15-5d94818988f9</project>

      <descr>Predicting retail sales, updated.</descr>
      <shared/>
      <longdescr/>
      <origin>Project original.</origin>
      <author>testuser</author>
      <authors>
        <author>testuser</author>
        <author>sheri</author>
      </authors>
      <cookie><![CDATA[  ]]></cookie>
      <lastmodified>1344377536002</lastmodified>
      <live>true</live>
    </project>
    <repository>
      <file>
        <filename>hello.txt</filename>
        <author>george</author>
        <authors>
          <author>george</author>
        </authors>
        <version/>
        <versionmsg/>
        <descr>Sample file stored from project directory.</descr>
        <tags/>
        <length>11</length>
        <type>text/plain</type>
        <latestby>george</latestby>
        <category>text</category>
        <shared/>
        <restricted/>
        <published/>
        <access>Private</access>
        <md5>5eb63bbbe01eeed093cb22bb8f5acdc3</md5>
        <lastModified>1378325756545</lastModified>
        <url>http://dhost:dport/deployr/r/repository/
        file/download/george/hello.txt</url>
      </file>
    </repository>
    <httpcookie>B1B5673DC4A358407F83FD6725A8C0BF</httpcookie>
  </response>

6.4.7 /r/project/directory/load

This call loads a file from the repository into the working directory for the specified project.

HTTP Method

POST

Request Format

Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=utf-8

Parameters

  • format – specifies markup encoding on the call: json or xml
  • project – specifies the project identifier
  • filename - specifies the repository file name
  • author - specifies the repository file author
  • version - (optional) specifies the repository file version

Examples 

format=json
project=PROJECT-4f9fe8bf-9425-4f2c-aa15-5d94818988f9
filename=sample.csv
author=testuser
version=

Response Markup (JSON)

{

6.4.8 /r/project/directory/download

This call downloads the working directory contents for the specified project.

By specifying a single value for the filename parameter, the caller can download a specific file. By specifying multiple values for the filename parameter, the caller can download a zip archive of those files. By omitting the filename parameter, then the caller can download a zip archive with all of the files in the working directory.

HTTP Method

GET

Request Format

Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=utf-8

Parameters

  • format – specifies markup encoding on the call: json or xml
  • project – specifies the project identifier
  • filename - (optional) specifies comma-separated file names for download
  • inline - (optional) if true, the Content-Disposition response header indicating attachment is omitted

Examples 

format=json
project=PROJECT-4f9fe8bf-9425-4f2c-aa15-5d94818988f9
filename=sample.csv

Response

If a single value for the filename parameter is specified on the call, then:

Content-Type: file/content-type

If multiple values for the filename parameter are specified or the parameter is omitted on the call, then:

Content-Type: application/zip

6.5 Working with the Project Package APIs

The project package APIs facilitate R package dependency management for projects.
  • Retrieve a list of all packages loaded for a project using the /r/project/package/list call.
  • Load individual packages for a project using the /r/project/package/attach call.
  • Unload individual packages for a project using the /r/project/package/detach call.

7 Working with the Job APIs

The Job APIs facilitate working with DeployR managed jobs. Jobs support the execution of commands in the background on behalf of users.

Submitting Jobs v Scheduling Jobs

Jobs can be submitted for immediate background execution using the /r/job/submit call. Jobs can be scheduled for execution at some later date or on a recurring basis using the /r/job/schedule call.

Job Scheduling Priority

When a user submits or schedules a job they can identify a high, medium or low (default) priority for their job. Each priority level has it's own dedicated jobs queue managed by the jobs scheduler.

Jobs in higher priority job queues are guaranteed to be executed on the grid ahead of jobs in lower priority job queues. Put another way, jobs in higher priority job queues are assigned free slots on the grid ahead of jobs on lower priority queues. Jobs on the same jobs queue are executed on the grid in the order in which they were submitted.

High, medium and low priority job queues allow users to expedite higher priority jobs by 'jumping the queue', and to expedite jobs to best fit specific scheduling needs.

Retrieving Job Results

Users can query the status of their jobs using the /r/job/query call which returns the current status for a given job. Users can cancel a scheduled job or an actively running job using the /r/job/cancel call.

Regardless of whether a job runs to completion or whether a job is interrupted or aborted by the user the DeployR server will create a new project for the user by default. This project will be named after the job that created it and will contain a complete workspace, working directory, package dependencies, command history and associated results generated by that job. The user can then work with the full set of Project APIs to manipulate, analyze, visualize and interpret all of the objects, files and generated plots resulting from the job.

However, if the storenoproject parameter is set to true when submitting the job then a project is not created when the job completes. Using the storenoproject parameter can be very resource efficient and improve throughput when the only data you care about has already been stored in the repository using the storeobjects and/or storefiles parameters.

If the storenoproject parameter is not set to true then a project is always created to hold the results of a job unless the job experiences a runtime error during execution, for example, the R code being executed on the job has syntax errors or attempts to reference undefined objects. In such cases, see the statusMsg property on a failed job for an indication of the underlying cause of the problem.

Important! All completed, interrupted and aborted jobs result in new projects for users.

Understanding the Jobs Lifecycle

The following diagram provides an overview of the full set of Job APIs and indicates the lifecycle of jobs managed by those APIs:

7.1 /r/job/list

This call lists jobs for the currently authenticated user.

The openonly parameter allows the caller to see only those jobs in an open state. The set of job open states are shown here:

  • Scheduled : job is scheduled but not yet queued for running.
  • Queued : job is queued for running.
  • Running : job is running.

Important! Any open job can be cancelled using the /r/job/cancel call.

HTTP Method

GET

Request Format

Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=utf-8

Parameters

  • format – specifies markup encoding on the call: json or xml
  • openonly – (optional) if true, only jobs in an open-state are listed in the response markup
  • extended - (optional) If true, additional data properties describing each job are listed in the response markup

Examples 

format=json

7.2 /r/job/submit

This call submits a job for background execution on behalf of the user.

To submit the execution of an arbitrary block of R code the caller must provide a value on the code parameter.

To submit the execution of a single repository-managed script the caller must provide parameter values for rscriptname , rscriptauthor and optionally rscriptdirectory and rscriptversion . To submit the execution of a chain of repository-managed scripts the caller must provide a comma-separated list of values on the rscriptname , rscriptauthor and optionally rscriptdirectory and rscriptversion parameters.

To submit the execution of a single external script the caller must provide a valid URL or file path using the externalsource parameter. To submit the execution of a chain of external scripts the caller must provide a comma-separated list of values on the externalsource parameter. Note, to submit the execution of an external script the caller must have been granted the POWER_USER role.

Note: A chained execution executes each of the scripts identified on the call in a sequential fashion on the R session for the job, with execution occurring in the order specified on the parameter list.

Please see the Standard Execution Model section in this guide for further details about the parameters on this call.

HTTP Method

POST

Request Format

Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=utf-8

Parameters

  • format – specifies markup encoding on the call: json or xml
  • name – job name
  • descr – (optional) job description
  • code – (optional) R code to execute on job
  • rscriptname – (optional) comma-separated list of repository-managed script filenames to execute on job
  • rscriptdirectory - (optional) comma-separated list of repository-managed directories for scripts, defaults to root
  • rscriptauthor – (optional) comma-separated list of authors, one author per rscriptname
  • rscriptversion – (optional) comma-separated list of versions, one version per rscriptname
  • externalsource – (optional) comma-separated list of URLs or file paths to external scripts

Pre-Execution Parameters

  • inputs - (optional) DeployR-encoded inputs
  • csvinputs - (optional) comma-separated list of primitive name/value inputs
  • preloadbydirectory - (optional) comma-separated list of repository directory names
  • preloadfilename - (optional) comma-separated list of repository filenames
  • preloadfiledirectory - (optional) comma-separated list of directories, one directory per preloadfilename
  • preloadfileauthor - (optional) comma-separated list of authors, one author per preloadfilename
  • preloadfileversion - (optional) comma-separated list of versions, one version per preloadfilename
  • preloadobjectname - (optional) comma-separated list of repository object (.rData) filenames
  • preloadobjectdirectory - (optional) comma-separated list of directories, one directory per preloadobjectname
  • preloadobjectauthor - (optional) comma-separated list of authors, one author per preloadobjectname
  • preloadobjectversion - (optional) comma-separated list of versions, one version per preloadobjectname
  • adoptworkspace – _(optional) identifies project whose workspace is to be adopted
  • adoptdirectory – _(optional) identifies project whose directory is to be adopted
  • adoptpackages – _(optional) identifies project whose package dependencies are to be adopted

On-Execution Parameters

  • cluster – _(optional) identifies a grid node cluster for targeted execution
  • priority - (optional) specifies the scheduling priority for the job: low (default), medium or high
  • tag - (optional) specifies a tag that labels the execution
  • echooff - (optional) if true R commands will not appear in the console output saved on the project execution history for the job
  • consoleoff - (optional) if true console output is not saved on the project execution history for the job
  • artifactsoff - (optional) when enabled, artfiacts generated in the working directory are neither cached to the database nor reported in the response markup
  • enableConsoleEvents - (optional) if true console events are delivered on the event stream when the job executes
  • graphics - (optional) specifies preferred R graphics device for execution: png or svg
  • graphicswidth - (optional) specifies preferred width for R graphics device images
  • graphicsheight - (optional) specifies preferred height for R graphics device images

Post-Execution Parameters

  • storefile - (optional) comma-separated list of working directory filenames
  • storeobject - (optional) comma-separated list of workspace object names
  • storeworkspace - (optional) filename (.rData) where workspace contents will be saved in the repository
  • storedirectory - (optional) repository directory for stored files and objects after the execution completes, defaults to root
  • storenewversion - (optional) if true, ensures each file stored in repository results in new version being created if needed
  • storepublic - (optional) if true, publishes each file stored in the repository
  • storenoproject - (optional) if true, no project persistence following job execution

Examples 

format=json
name=Submitted Analysis
descr=Demonstrates job submission.
rscriptname=Histogram of Auto Sales
rscriptauthor=testuser

Response Markup (JSON)

    "deployr": {
        "response": {
            "call": "/r/job/submit",
            "success": true,

                "job": "JOB-91baaca8-574d-4703-b225-97e64ec63e70",

                "timeCode": 0,
                "timeTotal": 0,
                "status": "Queued",
                "statusMsg": null,
                "project": null
            },
        }
    }
}

7.3 /r/job/schedule

This call schedules a job for background execution on behalf of the user.

The schedstart parameter identifies the start time for the job. This parameter value is specified as UTC in milliseconds. The schedrepeat parameter indicates the number of times the job is to be repeated, and if omitted the job is executed just once. The schedinterval parameter indicates the interval, measured in milliseconds, between repeat executions.

To schedule the execution of an arbitrary block of R code the caller must provide a value on the code parameter.

To schedule the execution of a single repository-managed script the caller must provide parameter values for rscriptname , rscriptauthor and optionally rscriptdirectory and rscriptversion . To schedule the execution of a chain of repository-managed scripts the caller must provide a comma-separated list of values on the rscriptname , rscriptauthor and optionally rscriptdirectory and rscriptversion parameters.

To schedule the execution of a single external script the caller must provide a valid URL or file path using the externalsource parameter. To schedule the execution of a chain of external scripts the caller must provide a comma-separated list of values on the externalsource parameter. Note, to schedule the execution of an external script the caller must have been granted the POWER_USER role.

Note: A chained execution executes each of the scripts identified on the call in a sequential fashion on the R session for the job, with execution occurring in the order specified on the parameter list.

Please see the Standard Execution Model section in this guide for further details about the parameters on this call.

HTTP Method

POST

Request Format

Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=utf-8

Parameters

  • format – specifies markup encoding on the call: json or xml
  • name – job name
  • descr – (optional) job description
  • schedstart - (optional) specifies the start time for job
  • schedrepeat - (optional) specifies the number of times job is to be repeated
  • schedinterval - (optional) specifies the interval (ms) on which job is to be repeated
  • code – (optional) R code to execute on job
  • rscriptname – (optional) comma-separated list of repository-managed script filenames to execute on job
  • rscriptdirectory - (optional) comma-separated list of repository-managed directories for scripts, defaults to root
  • rscriptauthor – (optional) comma-separated list of authors, one author per rscriptname
  • rscriptversion – (optional) comma-separated list of versions, one version per rscriptname
  • externalsource – (optional) comma-separated list of URLs or file paths to external scripts

Pre-Execution Parameters

  • inputs - (optional) DeployR-encoded inputs
  • csvinputs - (optional) comma-separated list of primitive name/value inputs
  • preloadbydirectory - (optional) comma-separated list of repository directory names
  • preloadfilename - (optional) comma-separated list of repository filenames
  • preloadfiledirectory - (optional) comma-separated list of directories, one directory per preloadfilename
  • preloadfileauthor - (optional) comma-separated list of authors, one author per preloadfilename
  • preloadfileversion - (optional) comma-separated list of versions, one version per preloadfilename
  • preloadobjectname - (optional) comma-separated list of repository object (.rData) filenames
  • preloadobjectdirectory - (optional) comma-separated list of directories, one directory per preloadobjectname
  • preloadobjectauthor - (optional) comma-separated list of authors, one author per preloadobjectname
  • preloadobjectversion - (optional) comma-separated list of versions, one version per preloadobjectname
  • adoptworkspace – _(optional) identifies project whose workspace is to be adopted
  • adoptdirectory – _(optional) identifies project whose directory is to be adopted
  • adoptpackages – _(optional) identifies project whose package dependencies are to be adopted

On-Execution Parameters

  • consoleoff - (optional) if true console output is not saved on the project execution history for the job
  • artifactsoff - (optional) when enabled, artfiacts generated in the working directory are neither cached to the database nor reported in the response markup
  • enableConsoleEvents - (optional) if true console events are delivered on the event stream when the job executes

7.6 /r/job/delete

This call deletes the specified job.

Only jobs in one of the success, cancelled or incompleted states can be deleted. The set of states are shown here:

  • Completed : job execution has run to successful completion.
  • Interrupted : job execution has been interrupted.
  • Cancelled : job has been cancelled.
  • Aborted : job execution has been aborted.
  • Failed : job execution has resulted in failure.

Jobs that are in an open-state can not be deleted.

Important! Deleting jobs will not delete the projects that resulted from those jobs.

HTTP Method

POST

Request Format

Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=utf-8

Parameters

  • format – specifies markup encoding on the call: json or xml
  • job - specifies a comma-separated list of job identifiers

Examples 

format=json
job=JOB-91baaca8-574d-4703-b225-97e64ec63e70

Response Markup (JSON)

{
    "deployr": {
        "response": {
            "success": true,
            "call": "/r/job/delete"
        }
    }
}

Response Markup (XML)

<deployr>
  <response>
    <success>true</success>
    <call>/r/job/delete</call>
  </response>
</deployr>

8 Working with the Repository APIs

The Repository APIs facilitate working with repository-managed files and directories.

Each authenticated user has access to their own private repository store. The repository acts as a persistent store for user files of any type, including binary object files, plot image files, data files, simple text files and files containing blocks of R code, which are referred to as repository-managed scripts.

By default, each private repository store exposes a single repository directory, known as the root directory.

Users can store files in and retrieve files from their root directory. In addition, users can manage their own set of custom and archived directories. Working with the root , custom and archived directories is detailed in the following section.

8.1 Working with the Repository Directory APIs

The Repository Directory APIs facilitate working with repository-managed directories.

Repository-managed directories fall into two distinct categories:

  1. User Directories
  2. System Directories

User Directories

Each authenticated user maintains their own set of private user directories. The set of user directories can be further divided into the following user directory types:

  1. Root directory
  2. Custom directories
  3. Archived directories

By default, each authenticated user has access to their own root directory in the repository. When Working with Repository Files, all API calls default to operating on the root directory if a specific custom or archived directory is not specified on the directory parameter.

Each authenticated user can also create zero, one or more custom directories. Each custom directory becomes a sub-directory of the root directory. Custom directories can be very useful to help manage logical groups of files across multiple projects, customers, applications etc.

Users can also archive the contents of their root directory or the contents of any of their custom directories within archived directories. This can be a very useful way to preserve old but valuable files over time while reducing day-to-day directory clutter.

By default, archived directories do not appear in the response markup when a user makes a call to /r/repository/directory/list. However, when the archived parameter is enabled on that call, any archived directories belonging to the user will appear in the response markup.

System Directories

System directories are virtual directories that exist only in the context of the response markup on the /r/repository/directory/list call. These directories are provided as a convenient way for a user working with the Repository Directory APIs to get access to repository-managed files that are shared or made public by other users.

There are just three system directories:

  1. Restricted directory
  2. Shared directory
  3. Public directory

The Restricted system directory maintains a list of files that have been shared-with-restrictions by other authenticated users. These files will have had their access controls set to restricted access.

The Shared system directory maintains a list of files that have been shared by other authenticated users. These files will have had their access controls set to shared access.

The Public system directory maintains a list of files that have been published by other authenticated users. These files will have had their access controls set to public access.

Important: As all files appearing in the system directories belong to other users, these files can not be copied, moved, modified, archived or deleted using the Repository Directory APIs.

8.1.1 /r/repository/directory/list

This call lists repository-managed directories.

By default, a list of the caller's user directories ( root and custom ) are returned in the response markup.

If the archived parameter is enabled then the list of the caller's user directories will include the caller's archived directories in the response markup.

A number of optional parameters are provided that allow the caller to request the addition of file lists for some or all directories:

If the userfiles parameter is enabled, the files in all of the caller's user directories are listed in the response markup. Note, depending on the number of files owned by the caller, when this parameter is enabled the response markup returned on this call can be a verbose.

If the directory parameter is specified then only the files in the directory indicated are returned in the response markup.

If the shared parameter is enabled then the files found in the Restriced and Shared system directories are returned in the response markup. If the published parameter is enabled then the files found in the Public system directory are returned in the response markup.

The categoryFilter parameter can be used to filter the types of files returned on the response markup. The following values are supported on this parameter:

  • R - returns only binary R object files with a .rData file extension
  • script - returns only R scripts with a .R or .r file extension
  • data - returns only data files with a .csv or .xls file extension
  • plot - returns only image files with a .png, .jpg or .svg file extension
  • shell - returns only shell script files with a .sh, .bash, .csh or .bat file extension
  • pdf - returns only PDF files with a .pdf file extension
  • text - returns only text files with a .txt file extension
  • other - returns any file type not matching the other file categories

For example, using a combination of the categoryFilter and directory parameters, a call can request only binary R object files found in a specific directory: /r/repository/directory/list?categoryFilter=R&directory=example.

Note: The metadata property in the response markup on this call is provided as a convenience for client application developers. It provides a complete list fo the user directories available to the current caller.

HTTP Method

GET

Request Format

Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=utf-8

Parameters

  • format – specifies markup encoding on the call: json or xml
  • archived - (optional) if true, files found in archived directories are included in the response markup
  • userfiles - (optional), if true, files in all user directories are listed in the response markup
  • directory - (optional), when specified, only files in the user directory indicated are listed in response markup
  • shared - (optional) if true, files that are restricted but visible or shared by other users are included in the response markup
  • published - (optional) if true, files that are published by other users are included in the response markup
  • categoryFilter - (optional) when specified, the list of files in response markup is limited to category: R (rData), script (R), data (csv, xls), plot (png, jpg, svg), shell (sh, bat), pdf, text, other
  • external - (optional) if true, this call returns directories found in the external repository, otherwise returns files found in the default repository

Examples 

format=json
userfiles=true
shared=true
published=true
archived=false

Response Markup (JSON)

8.1.2 /r/repository/directory/create

This call creates a repository-managed custom directory.

If the name of the new custom directory is already in use by the caller the response markup will indicate an appropriate error.

HTTP Method

POST

Request Format

Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=utf-8

Parameters

  • format – specifies markup encoding on the call: json or xml
  • directory - specifies the name of the new custom directory

Examples 

format=json
directory=demo

Response Markup (JSON)

{
    "deployr": {
        "response": {
            "httpcookie": "33FD71038423B94D52808244C24B1737",
            "success": true,
            "call": "/r/repository/directory/create",
            "repository": {
                "directory": {
                    "directory": "demo",
                    "owner": "george"
                }
            }
        }
    }
}

Response Markup (XML)

<deployr>
  <response>
    <success>true</success>
    <call>/r/repository/directory/create</call>
    <httpcookie>33FD71038423B94D52808244C24B1737</httpcookie>
    <repository>
      <directory>
        <directory>demo</directory>
        <owner>george</owner>
      </directory>
    </repository>
  </response>
</deployr>

8.1.3 /r/repository/directory/rename

This call renames an existing repository-managed user directory ( custom or archived ).

When renaming a user directory, all files in the source directory are automatically moved to the destination directory. If the destination directory already exists the call will be rejected and the response markup will indicate an appropriate error.

You can use this call to convert an archived directory back into a custom directory, essentially unarchiving the archived directory.

Note: You can not rename the root directory. To move files from the root directory use the /r/repository/directory/move call.

Important:

This call will only move files that are owned by a single author to the destination directory. If a repository-managed file in the source directory has multiple authors, as a result of collaboration using the /r/repository/file/grant call, the file will not be moved to the destination directory and a warning to that affect will be indicated in the response markup.

HTTP Method

POST

Request Format

Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=utf-8

Parameters

  • format – specifies markup encoding on the call: json or xml
  • directory - specifies the name of the user directory to be renamed, custom or archived
  • destination - specifies the new name for the destination custom directory

Examples 

format=json
directory=demo
destination=example

Response Markup (JSON)

{
    "deployr": {
        "response": {
            "httpcookie": "33FD71038423B94D52808244C24B1737",
            "success": true,
            "call": "/r/repository/directory/rename",
            "repository": {
                "directory": {
                    "directory": "example",
                    "owner": "george"
                }
            }
        }
    }
}

Response Markup (XML)

<deployr>
  <response>
    <success>true</success>
    <call>/r/repository/directory/rename</call>
    <httpcookie>33FD71038423B94D52808244C24B1737</httpcookie>
    <repository>
      <directory>
        <directory>example</directory>
        <owner>george</owner>
      </directory>
    </repository>
  </response>
</deployr>

8.1.4 /r/repository/directory/copy

This call copies one or more repository-managed files from a source user directory to a destination user directory.

If the filename parameter is specified, only those files indicated on that parameter are copied. Otherwise, all files in the source directory are copied.

To ensure copying files does not accidentally overwrite any existing files in the destination directory, all copied files are created as new versions in the destination directory.

HTTP Method

POST

Request Format

Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=utf-8

Parameters

  • format – specifies markup encoding on the call: json or xml
  • directory - specifies the name of the source user directory
  • destination - specifies the name of the destination user directory
  • filename - (optional) comma-separated list of filenames to be copied. If omitted, all files in the source directory are copied
  • filerename - (optional) comma-separated list of new filenames for copied files identified on filename parameter

Examples 

format=json
directory=root
destination=samples

Response Markup (JSON)

{
    "deployr": {
        "response": {
            "call": "/r/repository/directory/copy",
            "success": true,
            "httpcookie": "33FD71038423B94D52808244C24B1737"
        }
    }
}

Response Markup (XML)

<deployr>
  <response>
    <call>/r/repository/directory/copy</call>
    <success>true</success>
    <httpcookie>33FD71038423B94D52808244C24B1737</httpcookie>
  </response>
</deployr>

8.1.5 /r/repository/directory/move

This call moves one or more repository-managed files from a source user directory to a destination user directory.

If the filename parameter is specified, only those files indicated on that parameter are moved. Otherwise, all files in the source directory are moved.

To ensure moving files does not accidentally overwrite any existing files in the destination directory, all moved files are created as new versions in the destination directory.

Important:

This call will only move files that are owned by a single author to the destination directory. If a repository-managed file in the source directory has multiple authors, as result of collaboration using the /r/repository/file/grant call, the file will not be moved to the destination directory and a warning to that affect will be indicated in the response markup.

HTTP Method

POST

Request Format

Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=utf-8

Parameters

  • format – specifies markup encoding on the call: json or xml
  • directory - specifies the name of the source user directory
  • destination - specifies the name of the destination user directory
  • filename - (optional) comma-separated list of filenames to be moved. If omitted, all files in the source directory are moved

Examples 

format=json
directory=root
destination=samples

Response Markup (JSON)

{
    "deployr": {
        "response": {
            "call": "/r/repository/directory/move",
            "success": true,
            "httpcookie": "33FD71038423B94D52808244C24B1737"
        }

}

Response Markup (XML)

<deployr>
  <response>

  </response>
</deployr>

8.1.6 /r/repository/directory/update

This call updates repository-managed file access controls by directory.

If the filename parameter is specified, only those files indicated on that parameter are updated. Otherwise, all files in the source directory are updated.

HTTP Method

POST

Request Format

Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=utf-8

Parameters

  • format – specifies markup encoding on the call: json or xml
  • directory - specifies the name of the user directory, root or custom
  • filename - (optional) comma-separated list of filenames to be updated. If omitted, all files in the source directory are updated
  • restricted - (optional) comma-separated list of role names, making files visible to authenticated users with these roles
  • shared - (optional) if true, files are shared and visible to authenticated users
  • published - (optional) if true, files are published and visible to authenticated and anonymous users

Examples 

format=json
directory=demo
shared=true

Response Markup (JSON)

{
    "deployr": {
        "response": {
            "call": "/r/repository/directory/update",
            "success": true,
            "httpcookie": "33FD71038423B94D52808244C24B1737"
        }
    }
}

Response Markup (XML)

<deployr>
  <response>
    <call>/r/repository/directory/update</call>
    <success>true</success>
    <httpcookie>33FD71038423B94D52808244C24B1737</httpcookie>
  </response>
</deployr>

8.1.7 /r/repository/directory/archive

This call archives one or more repository-managed files from a source user directory ( root or custom ) to an archive directory.

If the value of the archive parameter indicates an existing archive directory then the files in the source directory are added to the existing archive. Otherwise, a new archive directory is automatically created on behalf of the caller. Archived directories automatically have a .archive postfix appended to their name if it is not supplied on the archive parameter value.

If all of the files in the source directory are successfully archived, the source directory is automatically deleted from the repository. If the source directory was root , an empty root directory is preserved. If any of the files in the source directory are skipped or can not be archived (see following note), those files and the source directory are preserved.

Important:

This call will only archive files that are owned by a single author to the destination directory. If a repository-managed file in the source directory has multiple authors, as a result of collaboration using the /r/repository/file/grant call, the file will not be archived to the destination directory and a warning to that affect will be indicated in the response markup.

HTTP Method

POST

Request Format

Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=utf-8

Parameters

  • format – specifies markup encoding on the call: json or xml
  • directory - specifies the name of the user directory to be archived, root or custom
  • archive - specifies the target name for the archived directory. If omitted, a .archive extension is automatically added
  • filename - (optional) comma-separated list of filenames to be archived. If omitted all files in the source directory are archived

Examples 

format=json
directory=example
archive=savedExamples

Response Markup (JSON)

{
    "deployr": {
        "response": {
            "httpcookie": "33FD71038423B94D52808244C24B1737",
            "success": true,
            "call": "/r/repository/directory/archive",
            "repository": {
                "directory": {
                    "directory": "savedExamples.archive",
                    "owner": "george"
                }
            }
        }
    }
}

Response Markup (XML)

<deployr>
  <response>
    <success>true</success>
    <call>/r/repository/directory/archive</call>
    <httpcookie>33FD71038423B94D52808244C24B1737</httpcookie>
    <repository>
      <directory>
        <directory>savedExamples.archive</directory>
        <owner>george</owner>
      </directory>
    </repository>
  </response>
</deployr>

This call uploads a set of files in a zip archive into an existing repository-managed user directory ( root , custom or archived ).

Request Format

  • directory - specifies the name of the user directory into which the files are to be uploaded
  • descr - (optional) specifies a description to associate with the uploaded file
  • tags - (optional) specifies tag words to associate with the repository file
  • restricted - (optional) comma-separated list of role names, which makes the file visible to authenticated users with these roles
  • shared - (optional) if true, the file will be shared which makes the file visible to authenticated users
  • published - (optional) if true, the file will be published which makes the file visible to authenticated and anonymous users
  • newversion – (optional) if true, the repository will create new version rather than overwrite
  • newversionmsg – (optional) if newversion is true, message to associate with new version

8.2 Working with the Repository File APIs

The Repository File APIs facilitate working with repository-managed files.

Because the repository supports versioned file storage multiple versions of any file can exist at any one time and any version can be retrieved upon request.

Each repository-managed file is uniquely identified on the API by the following parameters:

  1. filename - repository file name
  2. author - repository file author
  3. directory - (optional) repository directory name, if omitted, defaults to root directory.
  4. version - (optional) repository file version

Access to each repository-managed file is controlled by a set of properties on the file: restricted , shared and published respectively. These properties can be used to control the visibility of the file to other users, both authenticated and anonymous users. There are four distinct access control levels:

  1. Private - the default access level, the file is visible to it's author(s) only.
  2. Restricted - the file is visible to authenticated users that have been granted one or more of the roles indicated on the restricted property of the file.
  3. Shared - the file is visible to all authenticated users when the shared property is true.
  4. Public - the file is visible to all authenticated and all anonymous users when the published property is true.

Repository File Retrieval

  1. Retrieve a list of the files in the repository using the /r/repository/file/list call.
  2. Retrieve individual files in the repository using the /r/repository/file/download call.
  3. Retrieve a list of files per repository-managed directory using the /r/repository/directory/list call.
  4. Retrieve one or more files from a repository-managed directory using the /r/repository/directory/download call.

Repository File Creation

  1. Upload a file into the repository from the users computer using the /r/repository/file/upload call.
  2. Transfer a file into the repository from a URL using the /r/repository/file/transfer call.
  3. Write a text file into the repository using the /r/repository/file/write call.

Repository File Version Control

  1. Retrieve a list of all versions of a specific file in the repository using the /r/repository/file/list call.
  2. Retrieve a generated diff between any version of a text-based file and the latest version of that file using the /r/repository/file/diff call.
  3. Revert to an older version of specific file in the repository using the /r/repository/file/revert call.

8.2.1 /r/repository/file/list

This call lists repository-managed files.

The categoryFilter parameter can be used to filter the types of files returned on the response markup. The following values are supported on this parameter:

  • R - returns only binary R object files with a .rData file extension
  • script - returns only R scripts with a .R or .r file extension
  • data - returns only data files with a .csv or .xls file extension
  • plot - returns only image files with a .png, .jpg or .svg file extension
  • shell - returns only shell script files with a .sh, .bash, .csh or .bat file extension
  • pdf - returns only PDF files with a .pdf file extension
  • text - returns only text files with a .txt file extension
  • other - returns any file type not matching the other file categories

For example, using a combination of the categoryFilter and directory parameters, a call can request only binary R object files found in a specific directory: /r/repository/file/list?categoryFilter=R&directory=example.

HTTP Method

GET

Request Format

Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=utf-8

Parameters

  • format – specifies markup encoding on the call: json or xml
  • filename - (optional) when specified, call returns a list of file versions for the filename
  • directory - (optional) when specified, used in conjunction with filename parameter to identify specific file
  • shared - (optional) if true, files that are restricted but visible or shared by other users are included in the response markup
  • published - (optional) if true, files that are published by other users are included in the response markup
  • categoryFilter - (optional) when specified list of files in response markup is limited to category: R (rData), script (R), data (csv, xls), plot (png, jpg, svg), shell (sh, bat), pdf, text, other
  • external - (optional) if true, this call returns files found in the external repository, otherwise returns files found in the default repository

Examples 

format=json

Response Markup (JSON)

{
    "deployr": {
        "response": {
            "call": "/r/repository/file/list",
            "success": true,
            "repository": {
                "files": [

8.2.3 /r/repository/file/upload

This call uploads a file from the user's computer to the repository.

HTTP Method

POST

Request Format

Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=utf-8

Parameters

  • format – specifies markup encoding on the call: json or xml
  • filename - specifies the name of the file to upload
  • file - ...file content...
  • directory - (optional) specifies the target repository directory, defaults to root
  • descr - (optional) specifies a description to associate with the uploaded file
  • tags - (optional) specifies tag words to associate with the repository file
  • restricted - (optional) comma-separated list of role names, which makes the file visible to authenticated users with these roles
  • shared - (optional) if true, the file will be shared which makes the file visible to authenticated users
  • published - (optional) if true, the file will be published which makes the file visible to authenticated and anonymous users
  • newversion – (optional) if true, the repository will create new version rather than overwrite
  • newversionmsg – (optional) if newversion is true, message to associate with new version
  • inputs - (optional) specifies the inputs property on a repository-managed script
  • outputs - (optional)specifies the outputs property on a repository-managed script

Examples 

format=json
filename=demo.R
file=...file content…
descr=Sample R script.
restricted=MARKETING

8.2.7 /r/repository/file/diff

This call generates a diff between the current working copy of a file and a specific version found in the files version history.

HTTP Method

GET

Request Format

Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=utf-8

Parameters

  • filename - specifies the name of the repository file
  • author - specifies the repository file author
  • version - specifies the repository file version to diff against the current working copy
  • directory - (optional) specifies the target repository directory, defaults to root

Examples 

filename=demo.R
author=george
version=5022d53ff90c81559cb886f7

Response

Content-Type: text/html

8.2.8 /r/repository/file/revert

This call reverts the current working copy of a file to a specific version found in the files version history.

POST

Request Format

Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=utf-8

  • descr - (optional) specifies a description to associate with the new current working copy

  • shared - (optional) if true, file is shared and visible to authenticated users
  • published - (optional) if true, file is published and visible to authenticated and anonymous users

  • newversionmsg – (optional) if newversion is true, message to associate with the new version
  • inputs - (optional) specifies the inputs property on a repository-managed script
  • outputs - (optional) specifies the outputs property on a repository-managed script

newversion=true
newversionmsg=Reverting to July 2013 version of script.

8.2.9 /r/repository/file/grant

This call grants and/or revokes ownership rights on a repository-managed file.

If the caller is an owner of the file, the caller can:

  1. Grant ownership rights to one or more authenticated users and/or
  2. Revoke ownership rights for one or more owners.

As this API call is provided to support collaborative workflows, it assumes fair not malicious usage by owners.

Revoking ownership rights is equivalent to the caller deleting the file on behalf of the owners indicated on the revokeauthor parameter. The caller can even revoke their own ownership on a file by specifying their own username on the revokeauthor parameter which is equivalent to calling the /repository/file/delete call.

Notes on parameters:

  1. Unlike most repository APIs that require both filename and author parameters, there is no explicit author parameter on this call. The author is understood to be the caller.
  2. While the newauthor and revokeauthor parameters are shown as optional, a value must be provided for at least one of these two parameters, otherwise the call will fail and and error will be indicated in the response markup.

HTTP Method

POST

Request Format

Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=utf-8

Parameters

  • format – specifies markup encoding on the call: json or xml
  • filename - specifies the name of the repository file
  • newauthor - (optional) specifies a comma-separated list of grantee usernames
  • revokeauthor - (optional) specifies a comma-separated list of revokee usernames
  • directory - (optional) specifies the target repository directory, defaults to root

Examples 

format=json
filename=demo.R
newauthor=susan, henry
revokeauthor=moe

Response Markup (JSON)

{
    "deployr": {
        "response": {
            "call": "/r/repository/file/grant",
            "success": true,
            "repository": {
                "file": {
                    "filename": "demo.R",
                    "directory": "root",
                    "descr": "Sample R script.",
                    "author": "george",
                    "authors": [
                        "george",
                        "susan",
                        "henry"
                    ],
                    "version": null,
                    "versionmsg": null,
                    "latestby": "george",
                    "type": "text/plain",
                    "category": "script",
                    "tags": null,
                    "length": 6,
                    "md5": "77d7c62ca2bc4ac236235020fa3cb319",
                    "lastModified": 1378391625616,
                    "restricted": "MARKETING",
                    "shared": true,
                    "published": false,
                    "access": "Restricted",
                    "url": "http://dhost:dport/deployr/r/repository/
                    file/download/george/demo.R"
                }
            },
            "httpcookie": "2E8E6E359A838FEA20A74CA65E10A031"
        }
    }
}

Response Markup (XML)

<deployr>
  <response>
    <call>/r/repository/file/grant</call>
    <success>true</success>
    <repository>
        <file>
          <filename>demo.R</filename>
          <directory>root</directory>
          <descr>Sample R script.</descr>
          <author>george</author>
          <authors>
            <author>george</author>
            <author>susan</author>
            <author>henry</author>
          </authors>
          <version/>
          <versionmsg/>
          <latestby>george</latestby>
          <type>text/plain</type>
          <category>script</category>
          <tags/>
          <length>6</length>
          <restricted>MARKETING</restricted>
          <shared>true</shared>
          <published/>
          <access>Restricted</access>
          <md5>77d7c62ca2bc4ac236235020fa3cb319</md5>
          <lastModified>1378391625616</lastModified>
          <url>http://dhost:dport/deployr/r/repository/
          file/download/george/demo.R</url>
        </file>
    </repository>
    <httpcookie>29A3689D527FCA9C2F949985B82C2A83</httpcookie>
  </response>

8.2.10 /r/repository/file/download

This call downloads one-or-more repository-managed files.

When two or more files are being downloaded, the response type on this call is a zip archive file.

HTTP Method

GET

Request Format

Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=utf-8

Parameters

  • format – specifies markup encoding on the call: json or xml
  • filename - comma-separated list of filenames to be downloaded
  • author - comma-separated list of authors for named files
  • directory - comma-separated list of directories for named files
  • version - (optional) comma-separated list of versions for named files

Examples 

format=json
name=demo.R
author=george

Response

Content-Type: file/content-type

8.2.12 /r/repository/file/copy

This call copies one or more repository-managed files to the destination directory.

If the destination directory already contains a filename matching an incoming filename, then a new version of the file is automatically created.

GET

Request Format

Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=utf-8

Parameters

  • format – specifies markup encoding on the call: json or xml
  • filename - comma-separated list of filenames to be copied
  • directory - comma-separated list of directories for named files
  • destination - specifies the name of the destination user directory in the repository
  • version - (optional) comma-separated list of versions for named files
  • filerename - (optional) comma-separated list of new filenames for copied files identified on filename parameter

Examples

name=demo.R

directory=root
destination=samples

  </response>
</deployr>

8.3 Working with the Repository Script APIs

The Repository Script APIs provide some script-specific functionality for repository-managed scripts.

Scripts are blocks of R code with well-defined inputs and outputs. While scripts are technically also repository-managed files, scripts differ from other repository-managed files as they perform a very specific function that can be exposed as an executable on the API.

Important! Repository-managed scripts are files in the repository so all API calls described in the section Working with Repository Files are available to create and manage repository-managed scripts.

8.3.1 /r/repository/script/list

This call lists repository-managed scripts.

This call is available to authenticated and anonymous users. However, if the caller is an anonymous user then only published scripts will be returned in the response markup.

HTTP Method

GET

Request Format

Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=utf-8

Parameters

  • format – specifies markup encoding on the call: json or xml
  • filename - (optional) when specified, call returns list of script versions for filename
  • shared - (optional) if true, scripts shared by other users are included in the response markup
  • published - (optional) if true, scripts published by other users are included in the response markup
  • external - (optional) if true, this call returns scripts found in the external repository, otherwise returns scripts found in the default repository

Examples 

format=json
published=true

Response Markup (JSON)

{
    "deployr": {
        "response": {
            "call": "/r/repository/script/list",
            "success": true,
            "repository": {

                        file/download/george/demo.R"

                        "author": "susan",
                        "authors": [
                            "susan"

                        "version": null,
